When installing fixpack for RAD 60, the error "!MESSAGE Waiting... : 
org.eclipse.update.configurator 4997"  generated in the near end of 
installing. (the problem seems only occur if you have full RAD install with 
all the optional components). After talked to Updater poeple, the error 
probably generated from runtime. The numbers in the error message are slightly 
different each time, but all around 5000. Installing of fixpack can be 
completed successfully after clean up partilly installed files and re-start 
RPU.

I have to look at this more, but the message comes from the threading code in 
the update.configurator when it asks the OSGi runtime to resolve the bundles.

Did we update a bundle which the update.configurator depended on (i.e 
org.eclipse.core.runtime or org.eclipse.osgi?) or perhaps an nl fragment to 
update.configurator?  It looks like update.configurator is being refreshed 
from a call to PackageAdmin.refreshPackages.

I am hitting this same problem (I think)
As part of a larger update I am trying to update org.eclipse.platform.nls1 from 
3.0.1.1 to 3.0.2
Doing so causes the product to lose large amounts of functionality and spew to 
appear in the log until you can restart with -clean.
If I try to update just this feature by itself, it cause eclipse to become 
unstartable until -clean is applied.
Here is the log file you get when you try to update, as well as the logs from 
updating just the nls1 feature (eclipse now unstartable)

Unfortunately, I have no way of forcing the user to -clean, and the user now 
cannot access large amounts of function, nor can they uninstall the patch

I think these bugs are occurring because a fragment of one of the initial 
bundles (org.eclipse.core.runtime or org.eclipse.update.configurator) is being 
updated or uninstalled.  As a result the following is occurring:

1) update detects the new fragments (e.g. org.eclipse.update.configurator.nl1)
2) update uninstalls the old version of the fragment
3) update installs the new version of the fragment
4) update refreshes all the bundles which it uninstalled or updated.
5) the old fragment (org.eclipse.update.configurator.nl1) is included in the 
refresh list.  This causes the host bundle to be refreshed too
(org.eclipse.update.configurator)

refreshing org.eclipse.update.configurator while it is starting is causing 
these errors to occur because refresh must be able to de-activate 
update.configurator in order to refresh it.  This is not possible while the 
bundle is starting.

One possible fix for update.configurator to not refresh bundles it uninstalls 
which are fragments to one of the initial bundles.

Thanks Tom.
What happens if the new fragment has a different id, but it is meant to 
replace the old stuff (say, translated strings). Which fragment comes first on 
the plugin classpath?

The old fragment will be on the classpath of the host before the new 
fragment.  This should only be an issue until the framework is restarted (a 
second time).  After a restart the old fragment will be completely removed 
regardless of whether update did a refreshPackages on the removed fragment or 
not.

ok.  So what are we going to do here.  Seems like the current state is less 
than optimal.

Tom suggested:
I can think of two possible solutions:
1)  update.configurator should not call refreshPackages on any uninstalled 
fragments which are attached to any of the initial bundles.  If update avoided 
this then it would prevent update.configurator from being refreshed while it 
is starting.
2)  We can look into making refreshPackages not fail in this scenario.  I 
think this would not really be the correct behavior because we would continue 
to refresh the bundles even though we could not suspend all the bundles we are 
about to refresh.  This would likely cause unforseen issues.


#2 seems too risky for now.  there may be a variation on 1 that has just the 
update.configurator not get refreshed if it is in strating state.  That is, a 
very precise fix for this specific problem.  Perhaps more in 3.1.1 or 3.2?

There are a few things the framework is doing for update.configurator during 
the refreshPackages operation that will make this bug hard to fix.

The fix for bug 62260:
This bug had to do with new versions of a singleton bundle being installed 
into the framework.  When update.configurator would call refreshPackages on 
the new singleton bundle the resolver would not allow it to resolve because an 
older version was currently "in use".  The fix for this was for the framework 
to add in all singleton bundles with the same symbolic name into the list of 
bundles to be refreshed.  This fix allowed the new version to be selected.

We also do a similar thing for uninstalled bundles.  When refresh packages is 
called we automatically add in any uninstalled bundles into the refresh list.

This behavior in refreshPackages was supposed to make life easier on 
update.configurator, but it has taken a level of control away from the 
update.configurator agent.  Fixing this bug with option 1 from comment 10 will 
not work unless we also change refreshPackages to NOT do the "automatic" 
things mentioned above.  Unfortunately that means more work for 
update.configurator:

- to figure out what singleton bundles need to be added to the refreshPackages 
list (this should not be hard, I can provide a simple patch)
- to ensure that any uninstalled bundles are added to the refreshPackages list 
(I'm pretty sure update.configurator already does this thought, Dorian can 
confirm)

Our WBI Toolkit has encountered a similar issue with this bug and wanted to see
if the behaviour we are seeing is related. The logs and exceptions are identical
to those posted but we like to be sure the effect we see is because of said bug
report. I've included some of the logs in following attachments and the
scenarios we have run.

We are installing a subset of RAD minus EGL portals and crystal reports, then
applying a wrapped RAD 6001 upgrade minus the same options above, and then
applying the J2C. The 6001 and J2C are installed using the RPU and our own
policy.xml files.

The following is the issue we found and our interpretation:
"
When the installation process runs, Eclipse creates a plugin cache.
When we launch the workbench, the eclipse updater reconcile the cache with the
plugins being discovered.
There is a bug in the updater/runtime which throws exception and aborts plugin
loading.
Externally, it shows by a much faster loading time and by .log files in the
configuration dir.
The msg.validation.mft.builder plugin fails to load (explains why the NL
fragment name is missing)

The manual workaround is to delete the configuration directories (keep
config.ini) and restart
Launching workbench with -clean should do the same
"

It seems we need to start with a "-clean" everytime then ?

I've tried 3 scenarios and will include log files below:

1) Install 6001 and J2C with the 6001 update.properties still having their
initWorkbench property.
Errors shown in 2 log files in eclipse/configuration

2) Install 6001 and J2C with 6001 having no initWorkbench statement and the
Eclipse init changed from "-application com.ibm.jxesupport.initialize -nosplash"
to "-initialize -nosplash"
Error shown in 1 log file

3) Install 6001 only without J2C components
No error log file but the error is now shown in workbench of Eclipse under
Plugin Development Perspective

This is too old to be critical -reducing.

This issue has surfaced again and is a real pain.  I'm convinced that update.configurator has no chance of solving this.

I think the framework is going to need to do something to allow the refreshPackages operation to continue.  Currently it is failing hard and leaving the framework in an inconsistent state.

Created an attachment (id=55262)
3.2.x patch

This fix has been released to 3.3 M4.  Here is a patch against the 3.2.x stream.  The PackageAdmin javadoc is pretty clear here.

"For any exceptions that are thrown during any of these steps, a FrameworkEvent of type ERROR is fired containing the exception."

The exception should not prevent the operation from completing.  This patch allows the refreshPackages operation to complete so we do not leave the framework in an inconsistent state.  For bundles that we cannot suspend they will not be resumed when the package admin operation completes.

Created an attachment (id=55264)
3.2.x patch

previous patch had a typo in the comments.
Jeff, do you approve this fix for 3.2.2?
Fix released to 3.2.2.
